title: Yukari Kinga
text:
is a Japanese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. She is currently playing as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> for <a href="Sanfrecce%20Hiroshima%20Regina">Sanfrecce Hiroshima Regina</a> in the <a href="WE%20League">WE League</a>. She previously played for the <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Japan women's national football team</a>, winning a <a href="2011%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> and an <a href="Football%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">Olympic silver medal</a> before her international retirement in 2016.
Club career.
In Japan until 2013.
Kinga was born in <a href="Yokohama">Yokohama</a> on 2 May 1984. After graduating from high school, she joined <a href="Nippon%20TV%20Beleza">Nippon TV Beleza</a> in 2003 where she played as attacking midfielder and right-winger. In the <a href="2003%20L.League">2003 season</a>, she was given the <a href="Nadeshiko%20League">Nadeshiko League</a>'s Best Young Player award. During her time at Nippon TV Beleza, the club won the <a href="Nadeshiko%20League">Nadeshiko League</a> championship 5 times. In 2011, she moved to <a href="INAC%20Kobe%20Leonessa">INAC Kobe Leonessa</a> with international players <a href="Homare%20Sawa">Homare Sawa</a>, <a href="Shinobu%20Ohno">Shinobu Ohno</a> and <a href="Chiaki%20Minamiyama">Chiaki Minamiyama</a> due to financial strain at the club. At <a href="INAC%20Kobe%20Leonessa">INAC Kobe Leonessa</a>, the club won the <a href="Nadeshiko%20League">Nadeshiko League</a> championship for 3 years in a row (<a href="2011%20L.League">2011</a>–<a href="2013%20L.League">2013</a>). She was selected to the league's Best XI for 6 years in a row (<a href="2007%20L.League">2007</a>–<a href="2012%20L.League">2012</a>).
In January 2014, INAC's general manager revealed that Kinga had agreed to join English <a href="FA%20WSL">FA WSL</a> club <a href="Arsenal%20L.F.C.">Arsenal Ladies</a> and in February she officially signed the contract. At Arsenal, Kinga helped propel the club to reach the final of the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20FA%20Women%27s%20Cup">2014</a> <a href="FA%20Women%27s%20Cup">FA Women's Cup</a> which they won in a 2–0 margin over <a href="Everton%20L.F.C.">Everton</a>.
She re-signed with INAC Kobe in early 2015. In 2016, she began playing in the Australian <a href="W-League%20%28Australia%29">W-League</a> for <a href="Canberra%20United%20FC">Canberra United</a>. In October 2017, Kinga joined defending W-League champions <a href="Melbourne%20City%20FC%20%28W-League%29">Melbourne City</a>. In February 2019, she returned to Japan and joined <a href="Orca%20Kamogawa%20FC">Orca Kamogawa FC</a>. In October 2019, Kinga re-signed with Melbourne City. In February 2020, it was announced that Kinga would re-sign with Orca Kamogawa at the end of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20W-League">2019–20 W-League</a> season.
National team career.
In August 2002, Kinga was selected by the <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Japan U-20 women's national team</a> for the <a href="2002%20FIFA%20U-19%20Women%27s%20World%20Championship">2002 FIFA U-19 Women's World Championship</a>. On 29 March 2005, she debuted for the <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Japan women's national team</a> against <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia</a>. She was playing as an <a href="Attacking%20Midfielder">attacking midfielder</a> and <a href="Winger%20%28association%20football%29">right-winger</a> until 2007, when she was converted to <a href="rightback">rightback</a> by manager <a href="Hiroshi%20Ohashi">Hiroshi Ohashi</a>. After she converted her position, she became a regular player in the Japan national team. Japan won the <a href="2011%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2011 World Cup</a> in which Kinga played in the final, came second in the <a href="2015%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2015 World Cup</a> and earned a silver medal in the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">2012 Summer Olympics</a>. She played 100 games and scored 5 goals for Japan until her retirement in 2016.
